sp.p: Well, you are my friends, if you chance to hear of any mans death ſhortly, then ſay Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I hope you do not mean to kill any man i'th field, you do make me tremble, Ile aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No, no, ſweet-heart, do not tremble, I will but—
Loſe my honour? Ile be carv'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a Capon's this? pray let me perſwade you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis but in vain to perſwade me, I'm reſolv'd, if you love me, do not uſe any arguments: the Cupidinaean fires burn in my breſt, and like the Oven Etna I am full of ſquibs and crackers. I had almoſt forgot—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Oven Etna, Ile be baked then: what a fury are you in? he looks like the god of War.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The god of War? I think I have reaſon. Hillaria, I muſt, and I will, and all the world ſhall not hold me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But you ſhall not go away thus, till you be calmer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: O that I were a flea upon his lip,
There would I ſuck for ever and not skip.
I will carbonado him, his face doth far
Excell all other like a blazing ſtar
We mortals wonder at. Vouchſafe to caſt
Off the ſparkling diamond eyes thou haſt:
O let me go on, me thy vowed creature,
That is confounded with thy form and feature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is the fool mad?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has ſomething in his head, and it were out: but here comes our fathers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Antonio not heard of yet?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: This morning we wanted a Bride too, but ſhe was found, marry I cryed for her firſt. Father, come, my Brother Antonio, is but gone to look his Siſter: ha, my ſweet wench, when ſhal's to bed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I hope 'tis ſo, and yet he ſtays too long. Here's Gorgon: Sirra, where have you been all this day?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, I have made inquiſition, both my tongue and my feet have walked, but my Miſtriſs is not to be found or heard of, Ile aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Gorgon, haſt loſt thy ſences? here's Selina.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Miſtriſs! then we are all made.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But ſirra, your Maſter Antonio's gone.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Gone in wine, ſir, for joy of his ſiſters finding agen.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Go your ways, firra, and either bring me news of him, or look me in the face no more, you'l finde we jeſt not.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Pray' ſir, let me take my journey in the morning, the wedding night is fatal: I hope your Worſhip does but jeſt, I may be drunk to night, and wake early enough to be gone afore day too, I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray ſir, let him ſtay to night.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: By this hand there he is, where? did not I hear his voice?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Away ſirra.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I have been mad all this while, and now am like to be my own man again: ſince there is no remedy, Gentiles all good night. Gorgon begins to be a wandring Knight.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I cannot be heartily merry,: well let's leave theſe two without any more ceremonies, 'ttis late, all joys be multiplied on my Son and Daughter: good night, I do comfort my ſelf with hope of Antonio's return, and yet fears are great.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Lights there: ſo, ſo, welcome thou much expected night, I do ſalute thy black brows: come, my Selina, ſhalt find I have young bloud: Hillaria, do ſervice to your Mother, make her unready.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis time enough.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And why ſhould we looſe any? I pray thee let her come. I know 'tis your Virgin modeſty, loath to part with a Maidenhead, but it muſt off: come prethee be not idle: why, thou knoweſt I married thee, Selina, as thou loveſt me—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, by that love I muſt entreat you one thing.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Any thing, ſweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
To ratifie an ancient
vow I made.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Any vows, what is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vowed when ever I married, my husband ſhould not lie with me the firſt night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Should any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not any man.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Come, 'twas but a fooliſh vow, and muſt be broke. Not lie with me the firſt night? 'twere a ſin beyond incontinency. I had rather looſe half my eſtate, then miſs thee but an hour out of mine arms this night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis but one night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis an age, a world of time to me: why I have fed of Oyſter-pies, and rumps of Sparrows a whole moneth, in expectation of the firſt night, and leave it for a vow?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Indeed you muſt.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How? muſt, come? I know you but jeſt, this is but your device to whet me on, and heighten me, as if old age hath ſoakt up all my marrow. Hark you, how old do ye think I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Some threeſcore and ſeventeen.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Out upon thy judgement: why I am not above, by all computation, ſix or ſeven and thirty: I am reſtored, renew'd, when firſt I lov'd thee, by this hand I was.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſee then you would tire me, by this beard you muſt not lie with me to night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How? nay then I ſee you'l try my ſtrength: thus I could force you.

She has thrown me down, I know not how to take it, nor well how to bear it, my bones ake, a pox a Gaſparo, a my conſcience I am an old fool: ha? I will ſee more, and ſet a good face on't, you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, old? 'tis ſo, my ſpirits faint agen: what did you marry for?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To make an aſs of you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Thou credulous fool, didſt thou imagine I ſhould ever love thee, or lie with thee? but when I have a child would ſhame the
Father: Oh the Father of dotage, that like an inundation doth o'recome the little world of man, drown all his reaſon, and leave him ſpoild, even of his own common ſence. Didſt think I was a piece of ſtone ſawn out by Carvers Art, ſo cold, ſo out of foul, ſo empty of all fire to warm my bloud, I'de lie with thee, worſe then the frigid Zone, or Iſicles that hang on beard of winter? Have I with wearied patience lookt to ſee, when thou'dſt lay violent hands upon thy ſelf; for being ſo mad, ſo impudent to love me, and wouldſt thou bed me too? didſt thou not tremble to dare the holy Rites and nuptial Tapers? Oh impious ſacriledge! hence, go waſte thy ſelf with ſorrow, pine that half-ſtarv'd body, until thy bones break thy skin, and fall to duſt before thy face: nay, you ſhall endure me: for ſince y'ave tyed me to you, I will be thy conſtant Fury, worſe then Hags or Night-mare, if thou doeſt talk of Love, or ſeek to be at reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Selina, ſweet Selina, hear me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sweet? oh villanous preſumption!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Firſt, you ſhall never ſolicite me to lie with you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Never by this hand, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Stand bare in my preſence.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Stark-naked.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Run of my errands.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: To the worlds end.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And keep a whore under my noſe, nay I will allow it.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: If you will have it ſo, I am content.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Swear, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Fleſh and bloud, I do ſwear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, riſe. In hope of your conformity, I forbear to let the puniſhment be equal with your deſerts.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh, I have married a Devil, I ſhall be utterly diſgraced, if this be known: Pray ſweet wife, let me beg one requeſt of you, that you would not diſcredit me, I will be content to endure your pleaſure, do not forſake my houſe, I beſeech you that you would lie with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Shall you appoint my lodging?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh no, I do but humbly intreat you will be pleaſed to lie with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, ſince you ſubmit ſo reſpectively, I will tender your credit in that point upon your good behaviour, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am the worſe for you by forty marks. One thing more, vertuous wife, that you would not tell your father, nor any body elſe, how you have beaten me: Goodnight, ſweet vertuous wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, ha, Hillaria, my way to thee is free,
I have beat my paſſage, and I come to thee.

div.stage: Enter Felice like a Shepherdeſſe, Selina, Shepherds.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I had thought the woods and ſuch wild groves as theſe, had been the houſe of rapine, and could not afford humanity, beaſts, and men like them, are wont to make ſuch places deſolate: did Nature make you thus at firſt, and are we that have Cities, houſe, and Civil Laws more rude then you? or hath all vertue choſe you as divine earth to dwell upon? Shepherdeſs, indeed I am in love with your wild kingdom here, and would not be a King abroad, if I might be jubject with ſuch fair Nymphs as you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Oh ſon, you would ſay ſo,
When our pleaſures all you know:
We are not oppreſt with care,
With which you in Cities are,
A Shepherd is a King, whoſe Throne
Is a moſſie Mountain, on
Whoſe top we ſit, our crook in hand,
Like a Scepter of command,
Our ſubjects, ſheep grazing below,
Wanton frisking to and fro.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: We nothing fear, awake nor ſleep,
But the Wolf goddild our ſheep,
On a Countrey Quill each plays
Madrigals, and pretty Lays
Of paſſions, and the force of Love,
And with Ditties heaven move.
Birds will liſten to our ſong,
And to leavy Arbours throng,
To learn our notes, and Miſtriſs name,
Vallies ecchoing with the ſame.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.l: When we hunt, as there is ſtore
Of Deer, the trembling Hare, and Bore,
You would think that you had ſeen
Gods in Shepheards weeds agen.
A hundred pretty Nymphs apace
Tripping ore the lands, and chaſe,
As many Lads, the gentle air
Playing with their dangling hair.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sometimes we dance a Feary round,
Hand in hand upon the ground,
Shepheards piping, Garlands crowning,
With our harmleſs boſoms drowning.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Walk unto the ſilver brook,
You ſhall need no other hook,
To catch the dancing fiſh withal,
But a ſong, or Madrigal.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: When the clouds let fall their ſhowres,
We have at hand a hundred bowres,
Where under Sweet-bryer, ſafe are we
And honey-dropping woodbine tree,
Here in ſpight of ſtorms we tell
Stories of love, of Philomel,
Of Paris, and the Golden ball,
Of Eccho, and Narciſſus fall.

sp.speaker: 3. Shep.
sp.l: Here no falſe-love brings deſpair,
Jealouſie, or ſuſpition, care,
Always happy moſt of all
On Silvanus feſtival.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: No more, good Shepheards, you undoe a boy with the opinion of his happineſs: if a few Jewels I have brought with me, may find acceptance here, I ſhall beſtow them as freely as your loves have faln on me. Nay then, Ile force 'em on you, I have left to purchaſe a Flock with you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: We thank you, gentle boy, gooden,
We muſt to our Flocks agen.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: But Shepheardeſs, or ſiſter if thou wilt, oh would thou wert, I prethee call me brother, Hath Love a part among you, tell me pray, what puniſhment inflict you on falſe love? But ſure you are exempt from ſuch a miſery: what then is her reward, that out of peeviſhneſs contemns the honeſt paſſion of her Lover, infults upon his vertue, and doth place unworthily her affection?

sp.speaker: Fel,
sp.l: Though ſuch a woman need no curſe,
Being one her ſelf, or worſe,
Yet we Shepherds uſe to ſay,
May ſhe love another day,
And not be lov'd, die in deſpair,
And have no other Tomb but air.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Prey, a prey! where did you get that face? that goddeſs face? it was Selina's once: how came you by it? did ſhe on her death-bed bequeath her beauty as a legacy, not willing it ſhould die, but live and be a laſting death to Infortunio? oh ſhe was cruel, not to bury it with her! but I am a fool, 'tis Venus and her Son, where be your Bow and Arrows, little Cupid? didſt thou maliciouſly ſpend all thy Quiver upon my heart, and not reſerve one ſhaft to make Selina love me? tell me, Venus, why did you uſe me ſo? you ſhall no more be Queen of Love. Stay, ſtay, Cupid was blind, how comes he now to ſee? yes, he did ſee, he never could have wounded me ſo right elſe. Why then let Fortune have her eyes again, and all things ſee how wretched I am made.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Oh, is there not within the power of Art, how to reſtore this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: There is, and out of that experience we have in theſe woods, of ſimples, I doubt not, but to apply a remedy.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: He will be worthy of your care herein, and ſhould he be, which I cannot imagine, ingrateful to your skill, I would reward it, and call you Mother and Siſter for it.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: It ſeems you have ſome relation to him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
Indeed he is the deareſt friend I had: and if my bloud were powerful to reſtore him, i'de ſpend it like a prodigal. I know Selina. Inf. Ha, do you know Selina? ſhe's married to Rufaldo, the old Uſurer, that went to bed afore to his money, and begat forty ith' hundred: now he beds Selina, and lays his rude hand o're her ſacred breſt, embraceth her fair body, now he dares kiſs her, and ſuck Ambroſia from her lip. Thoſe eyes that grace the day, now ſhine on him, he her Endimion, ſhe his ſilver Moon, the tongue that's able to rock Heaven aſleep, and make the Muſick of the Spheres ſtand ſtil, to liſten to the happier airs it makes, and mend their tunes by it: that voice is now devoted to his ears, thoſe cheeks, thoſe hands, would make gods proud to touch, are by his touch profaned every hour: oh, this makes me mad, but I will fit 'em for it, for Ile die, it may be then ſhe'l weep, and let fall tears upon my Grave-ſtone, which ſhall be of Marble, and hard like her, that if ſhe pour out floods, no drops ſhall ſink
thorow it to ſoften me, I will be wrapt in Lead to keep out prayers, for then I know, ſhe'l beg I would be friends: But then I will be juſt, and hate her love, as ſhe did mine, & laugh to ſee her grieve

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Come, I will fetch Selina to you, if you will ſleep.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Will you then? I will live, and you ſhall be my beſt boy.
sp.l: Come, I ſcorn to weep, or ſhed another tear:
Sit down, He have a Garland for my Boy,
Of Phoenix feathers: Flowers are too mean
To ſit upon thy temples; in thy face
Are many Gardens, Spring had never ſuch:
The Roſes and the Lillies of thy cheeks
Are ſlips of Paradiſe, not to be gathered, but wondred at.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: But you ſaid you would ſleep: when ſlept you laſt?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: I remember, before I lov'd, but that I knew not when I ſlept ſoundly, and dreamt of gathering Noſegays. 'Tis unlucky to dream of herbs and flowers.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: For Selina's ſake Ile try my beſt skill on him, get him to ſleep, your preſence I ſee is powerful, yonder's a pleaſant Arbor, procure him thither while I prepare the herbs, whoſe precious juice may with Heavens bleſſing make him well again.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: A thouſand bleſſings on you. Come, ſir, go with me, and when you have ſlept, Ile fetch Selina to you.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Prethee do, I am very drowzy: come, Ile dream of ſome thing, my eyes are going to bed, and leaden ſleep doth draw the curtains ore them.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Yes, and we will pick a diſh of Strawberries.

div.stage: Enter Jenkin, having laſt his way.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Has almoſt loſt her ſelf in theſe woods and wilderneſſes, was very weary of theſe journeys and travels in foot-backs: have not ſince her comings beheld any reaſonable creatures: bleſs us awl, Jocarello is loſt too, cannot tell where, in theſe mazes and labyrinths. Jocarello, ſo ho.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: So ho.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ha, there's ſome bodies yet, hark you tere, here is a Sentilman of Wales, look you, deſires very much to have ſpeeches and confabulations with you: where is her?

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: Here is her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Here is her? knaw not which ways to come to her: pray you tell Jenkin where you be?

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: Booby.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
Poobies? was her call her poobies? 'tis very ſaucy travels, her will teach her better manners and moralities, if her get her in
reaches and circumferences of her Walſh blades truly.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How, lies and poobies too? hark you, Jenkin was give you mawls and knocks, for your poobies, and lies, and indignities, look for your pates now.
Here is no bodies but buſhes and bryers, look you, awl is very quiet: ſo ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: Her am very much deceiv'd, now comes into our minds if theſe voices be not Ecchoes, Eccho.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Eccho.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, but her marvel much, have her Ecchoes in theſe Countries, pray you?

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Yes pray you.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Warrant her 'tis a Welſh Eccho, was follow Jenkin in loves out of Wales.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Out of Wales.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, bleſs us awl now, her call to remembrances and memories, her had communications and talkings with this very Ecchoes in Clamorgan-ſhire, in de vallies and Talles there look you, her am very glad her hath met with Ecchoes, was born in her own Countries, hark you, Jenkin was travel hither out of loves and affections to Selina.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Nay.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Nay, yes very true, pray you tell her, be Selina in theſe woods, or no?

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: No, where is her den, have her taken awl theſe labours and ambulations in vanities? ſay you, ſhall Jenkin then go back as he came?

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Aſſe he came.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Gone? It is not poſſible, hit may be Selina was turn ſpirits and be inviſible rather, ſhe is not gone verily.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: There you lye.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Lye, very well, you have priviledges to give lies and awl things in the world, but her will not leave theſe woods for awl dat, her will be Pilgrims all tays of her lifes, ere her go without her.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Goe without her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How, not love Jenkin? then there is a Devil in awl female ſexes: know very well ſhe promiſe loves and good wills in times, great while ago, pray you now, her will talk no longer with you. Fare you well Ecchoe, pray if you meet her Pages, bid her make haſts and expeditions after her. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
I think Jupiter has ſnatch'd up my Maſter Antonio, to make a Ganimede on him, he is not to be found yet, I have ſearcht all the Taverns ith Town, I am ſure, and that method my noſe led me to hoping he had been a good fellow, but, non eſt inventus, well,
my ſtock is ſpent, but with this terrible face a buff Jerkin, and a noaring basket-hilt, Gorgon will have a trick of wit to bear his own charges: but here comes a Gentleman, to my poſtures now.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Good your worſhip beſtow a ſmall piece of ſilver upon a poor Soldier, new come out of the Low-Countries, that have been in many hot ſervices, againſt the Spaniard, the French, and great Turk. I have been ſhot ſeven times through the body, my eyes blown up with gun-powder, half my skull ſeard off with a Canon, and had my throat cut twice in the open field: good your worſhip take compaſſion upon the caterwaking fortunes of a forlorne Gentleman, that have loſt the uſe of my veins, good your generous nature take compaſſion upon me, I have but four fingers and a thumb upon one hand: can work, and woonnot, one ſmall piece of grateful ſilver, to pay for my lodging, I beſeech you venerable fir.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Canſt not ſee?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Onely a little glimmering, ſir, the beams of your gentility have radiated, and infuſed light into my poor lanterns, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Can you feel then?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh ſir, that faculty alone, fortune and nature have left inviolated.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Here's ſomewhat for thee. What, can you ſee now?

div.stage: He kicks him, and Gorgon opens his eyes.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Gaſparo, is it you? Pox on your benevolence.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Whence came this project of wit?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: From the old predicament. Faith, neceſſity that has no Law, put me into this habit: my Maſter is turn'd coward, and ran away from me.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: And thou art turn'd Soldier, to fight with him when you meet agen: then thou wanteſt a Maſter? hark ſirra, what ſayſt thou to another project?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Oh, I could caper for't.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I am now leaving the world, and going into the Countrie, woot turn Gipſie, or Shepheard? I am for the woods, canſt Madrigals yet?

lg.l: Phillis fair, do not diſdain
The Love of Coridon thy Swain.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Excellent! wee'l turn Shepheards preſently, thou ſhalt be Phillis, and Ile be Coridon: let me alone to provide Ruſſets, Crook, and Tarbox: they ſay there's good hoſpitality in the Woods, and Songs and paſtimes upon Silvanus day.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: But that were pretty, ſhall I be a woman?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
By any means, thou haſt a good face already, a little ſimpering will do it, Ile accommodate thee early, keep thy own counſel, and Ile warrant thee
for a Maid-marrian.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: 'Sfoot! ſhall I run into my coats agen? go to, put me into what ſhape you will, Ile play my part: me thinks I do feel an hundred rural Animals taking up my petticoat already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray' forward with your relation.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: As I was ſaying, having challenged Antonio for the affront he did me before Hillaria, here by heaven, you muſt ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He did accept the Challenge, and the weapons were ſoon agreed upon, and we met: but not a word of fighting, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not come to fighting yet your ſelf: but by the way, what were your weapons?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A long ſword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas long ere you could remember it, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Soon as we came into the place appointed, we looked about, and ſaw all clear.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: As clear as day on your ſide.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We drew, but not a word of fighting, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not by that hand.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We threw our doublets off, to ſhew we had no Coat of Mail, or privy ſhirt upon us, againſt the Laws of Duelling: in fine, I bid him ſay his prayers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas well thought upon, and what did you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I let 'em alone, for I knew I ſhould kill him, and have time enough to ſay 'em afterwards at my leaſure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: When he had prayed, what then?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: When he had ſaid his prayers, he thought upon it, and let fall words tending to reconcilement: A my conſcience, he would have asked me forgiveneſs, but I ſtood upon my honor, and would fight with him, and ſo we ſtood upon our guard: but not a word of fighting, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh, by no means, but when did you fight?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ile tell you, Antonio when he ſaw no remedy, but that I would needs fight with him, and ſo conſequently kill him, made a deſperate blow at my head, which I warded with my dagger, better than he looked for, and in return, I cut off his left hand, whereat amazed and fainting, I nimbly ſeconded it, as you know I am very nimble, and run my Rapier into his right thigh, two yards.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then you were on both ſides of him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your Rapier, did you not ſay your weapons were long ſwords?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
But mine was both a ſword and Rapier, there's it, but not a word of fighting, as you love me: well, not to weary you with the narration of the innumerable wounds I gave him, I cut off
every joynt from his toe upwards, to his middle, by theſe hilts: now you may believe me, there ended Antonio my rival, judge, judge now, whether Bubulcus be valiant or not, but not a word of fighting, as you love me, let it die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas very valiantly done.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hark you, Sweet-heart, do you not remember who this is, that you have diſcovered this buſineſs too? this is Selina, his own fiſter.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What a Rogue was I, not to remember that?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do not you know that ſhe is my Mother-in-law? nay, nay, pluck up a good heart, what will you do? there's no running away.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Have you never an empty cheſt?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, to hide your ſelf? that I know you would not do for your credit: draw your ſword, and ſtand upon your guard, we know you are valiant, that could kill Antonio ſo bravely.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Hillaria, if ever you lov'd me, oh, I have made a fair piece of work, would you not tell me it was his ſiſter? oh, here they come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He hath confeſt it, ſir, your Daughter heard it, ſir, I charge you lay hands upon that murtherer, he hath ſlain my Brother Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Did you hear him confeſs it?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Here's right, confeſs and hang'd now.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs I did.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Bubulcus kill Antonio?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By this hand I do not know how to deny it for my credit.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay then lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes Father, Rufaldo. Selina, oh, a plague of all coxcombes, what a Rogue was I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will have Juſtice, away with him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am a lying Raſcal by this hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We muſt require Antonio from you, ſir, or your blood anſwer his. Away with him, Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ile be hang'd then, father Hillaria, will you ſee me hang'd?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: There is no remedy: would thou hadſt kild his Siſter; I am plagued with her, and dare not ſpeak it for ſhame, Ile do what I can to get a Reprieſe for you; nay, and you kill folks, you you muſt eene take your fortune.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A curſe of all ill fortune, I kil'd no body.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Away, I ſay, out villain, hence, for I Do hear my Brothers bloud for juſtice cry.

div.head: Actus quintus, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: I do not know this place, nor who you are, nor know I yet my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: That name I once did anſwer to, but then I was not baniſht to a wilderneſs, nor ſlept on ſuch a bed. Oh, if I be he, whom you call Infortunio, tell me how I came hither, doſt thou weep? I prethee tell me, boy, why do thoſe tears drown thy fair cheeks? but that they will not ſhew manly in me, I'de force my eyes to weep too, and we would ſit upon a bank, and play droptear, till one were bankrout. You amaze me: I ask how I came hither? anſwer me with other language, if you do not mean I came by water, which you might expreſs too in words as well, nay, better, for you now are cruel to your ſelves, and murder me: tell me, or I ſhall be mad.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Oh, ſtay: that brought Infortunio hither, you have now told your ſelf, diſtraction brought you.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Ha diſtraction? now you increaſe my wonder: was I mad, or do not you by anſwering, ſtudy to make me ſo? why ſhould I be mad, or being ſo, how came I well again? for if I dream not, I am well and calm.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You owe this Shepherdeſſe for your reſtore, whoſe skill heaven made ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Did you, fair Shepherdeſſe reſtore me then, and by your art recover natures loſs? all my well-beings yours: but yet if you could ſo Phyſician-like cure the diſeaſe which is but the effect of ſome diſtemper, you then ſhould know the cauſe: for elſe you are uncertain in your applications. Pray tell me then, why was I mad?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: This Lad can tell you that, better then I, but if his ſorrow will not let his tongue deliver it, Ile tell you ſir; you were in love.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: With whom, I pray.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: One whom they call Selina.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Ha, Selina? in what a depth of black forgetfulneſs is Infortunio fallen into? Selina, could I forget Selina? oh Shepherdeſs, I was not mad till now: for can I be my ſelf, and forget her? oh, in this queſtion I am undone: for I do hold my ſelf and all my underſtanding by her name, I am a begger, ſhe hath purchas'd all, nor am I maſter of one thought of comfort I borrow not from her: what curſe was faln upon my memory, to forget Selina?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
Sir, you remember her too well, unleſs ſhe would deſerve
it better.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: It is not in her power to deſerve, boy, for ſhe is now beholding for her ſelf unto another. Oh, this tares my ſoul, you did not well to releaſe me of my furies, and make me ſenſible again of that was my firſt corroſive, it was unfriendly: Oh, 'twas a happineſs to be mad, ſtark mad, for ſhe being loſt, what have I elſe to loſe? I was all hers, I gave my ſelf away: and deeds of gift ſhould hold.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Why ſhould you be ſo paſſionate? let once reaſon ſo late recovered, teach you love your ſelf, reſerv'd for nobler fortune.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: It is true, I am a very fool in doing ſo, and will you be my Miſtriſs then, and teach me how to forget my ſelf? what ſaiſt boy? ſhall I be Shepherd too? I will live here, and have thy company, thou art like my Love, ſhall we Shepherdeſs?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Come let's ſit down a while, nature hath ſpred her Carpets for us here, this is the loweſt, and yet 'tis higher then a Palace: pray teach me your Shepherds life, now I do long to be a woodman too, and you ſhall do a double cure upon me.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Stay, yonder are ſome Shepherds, lets on this bank ſit down and prattle. And how long iſt, ſince your Sweet-he art forſook you?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: It will be a quarter of a year next graſs.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Alas, poor Mopſa, but come, put him out of thy minde, ſing him away.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Laugh, and ſing him to his grave, ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: And never love him more.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Oh no, his love like a canker hath eat ſuch a great hole into my heart, I cannot for get him, but Ile ſing a ſong of him.

div.stage: Gorgon ſings a ſong, all this while, Gaſparo eyes Felice.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Prethee do.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Here's innocence of all ſides, who would live out this Common-wealth, where honeſt Swains with craft and falſhood, all their ſouls are clad in true ſimplicity: I will take a truce with care a while, to talk with this poor wench.

sp.speaker: Mopſa
sp.p: I heard you nam'd, pray tell me, were you in love?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: With whom forſooth?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: With a Gentleman that has prov'd unkinde, forſooth, broken his vows, and oathes, forſooth, he made much of me, time was, before his father dyed, forſooth, who was a good Yeoman, then he kiſt me, forſooth, and coll'd ſurreverence, but now he ſcorns Mopſa: I was his equal once, and have danced with him upon our Church green in a Morris ere now.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Alas, alas, has forſaken thee?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He is now about to commit makrimonial buſineſs with a young Girl I wiſs.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe. Ile have a trick to know it.
Bleſſings on you Shepherdeſs,
Yet by this hand, you are no leſs,
You were in love with a fair man,
Croſt by a father, began
This Shepherds life, and ruſſet weed,
Is it not the truth, I reed? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sir, are you a Fortune-teller?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: No, I am a fool, and yet I know
Something, though you think not ſo.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Do you ſee all this here?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: That, and more in this table
Lies your ſtory: 'tis no ſable,
Not a line within your hand,
But I eaſily underſtand:
Your Line of Life is fair, hard by
Aſcends that of Proſperity,
But broken in the midſt to th' Mount
Of Saturn here, which ill we count,
Ha, Triangle and Mercurial Line?
But Venus is no friend of thine.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: How now, Palmiſtry? believe him not.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: In your face your fate is wrote,
You lov'd a woman, ſhe not you,
You know whether I ſay true,
Her name began with S, but ſhee,
Shall never be enjoyd by thee,
She's married now to one that's old,
But very rich: your fortune's told.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Beſhrew me he has cunning.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Do you believe him, ſir?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Believe him? nay, you may believe him, he's abomination cunning man, he told me my fortune as right as if he had been in my belly.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.p: Does thy fortune lie in thy belly then, Sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Partly, ſir, as other womens fortunes do.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: Damſel, you have yet a fate
Will make you wonder more thereat,
By collection, I dare prove,
That his name, whom you did love,
Began with G. but 'tis too true,
He hath ſlain himſelf for you.
sp.p: Felice, come again, do not believe me, I told thee falſe, I did but try to gain a knowledge of thee: thy ſtars owe thee more happineſs, Felice, look up, ſee thy friend alive, I am Gaſparo. 'Sfoot, I ha made fair work.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Ha, 'tis Gaſparo.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Have I found thee, O wench, thou wert unjuſt, too much unjuſt, thus to abſent thy ſelf from Gaſparo; thy cruel father ſince hath wept enough to waſh away his error. Fates, I do thank you, for this bleſt direction But Infortunio, I am ſorry now, I read the truth of thy unhappineſs: it is too true, Selina is beyond your ſphere of hope: pardon, worthy ſir, the ſhape I took, was not to mock your fortunes, but try mine own. And have I found the wench?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, no, no, your ſuit is in vain, hands off, Shepherds.

sp.speaker: 1 Shep.
sp.p: I will make thee amends and marry, prethee ſweet Mopſa, beautiful Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Beauty! I do confeſs I have a reaſonable beauty, for black and white, for all other colours are but compounded of them: but the truth is, I cannot forget my old Love; though he hath prov'd falſe unto me, Mopſa will prove true unto him: oh, and it were not for ſhame, now I could die for love.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Be not dejected, ſir, you have a fate doth ſmile upon you, I have a little skill: in that this Gentleman ſeem'd to have ſome knowledge, I muſt needs croſs his judgement, and pronounce you are more happy.

l.hi: Let not ought your ſoul annoy,
You that Virgin ſhall enjoy,
That you firſt lov'd, who doth wait
To make your wiſhes fortunate,
And ere the Sun declines to Weſt,
You may be with marriage bleſt.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: The Boy is mad.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Do not undo, ſweet boy, the benefit thou haſt already done me, thou doſt utter impoſſibilities.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Then with one Argument I can eaſily take off your wonders, look on thy Selina, that on the wedding morn, forſook Rufaldo, touth'd with a ſenſe of thy indignities, thus to obſcure me from all curious ſearch and inquiſition, but not hoping ever to be made thine; now if true love maintain the opinion you pretend, thus in your arms I powre my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: It is Selina. Oh, I am rent in pieces with joy and wonder.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.l: Hark you, ſir, do not believe him,
Let not paſſion make you a mockery.
sp.p: Is not Selina married to Rufaldo? then am I Gooſe-giblet: I ſhould have been at Church with 'em, but for a crotchet that I had in my pate all the morning: I ſpake with her father yeſterday, and from his mouth I heard Selina was very well, I think I do not dream, indeed now I call to memory, he ſaid Selina was miſt two or three hours ath' wedding morn; ſome figary, I know not what: and Antonio, as I ſuppoſed, gone in queſt of her, not heard of ſince: but Selina is ſure Rufaldo's wife, or ſome devil in her likeneſs has abuſed them all with credulity. This is true, ſir, therefore be not eaſie, do not deſerve more pity, this boy is mad, a jugling boy.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Shall I not be believed then for my ſelf? Am I refuſed now?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: It cannot be ſhe: troth boy, thy conceit took me at firſt with much credulity: but here's our natures weakneſs, apt to credit what we affect: were there not too much againſt it, thou mighteſt deceive me: oh no, Infortunio is given up, loſt to all felicity.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Since then you put me, ſir, to prove my ſelf, let me not be loſt, I will not call you what I deſire, nor name you ſiſter: give me leave to finde my ſelf, I know not where I am yet: my brother Antonio gone? what fury hath aſſum'd Selina's ſhape?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Come, put on a mans ſpirit Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Well ſir, in regard you are ſo portunate, although I have forſworn Marriage, if you deſiſt conſtant, you may chance to have a lick at my Maydenhead.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I have it, my Brother's loſt: Ile ſend a ſhepherd in Antonio's name, to invite my Father hither, and that Incubus. I vow not to forſake theſe Plains, till I poſſeſs my ſelf, or be rejected quite, ſuſpend thy paſſions then awhile, Selina, to morrow is the Shepherds Holiday, which they ſolemnize with rutal pleaſures, 'twill draw them ſooner: ha, are they gone? I will not leave 'em, with this thread I ſhall tread o're the Labyrinth, and diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Antonio ſlain! hapleſs Cornelio, my hopes were treaſur'd up in him, the ſtaff and comfort of my age, and is he gone?

sp.speaker: Hil
sp.p: Haſt ſent for Bubulcus?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have, Father, let not too much paſſion ſoyl that temper hath been obſerv'd in old Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why, was not he thy Brother? canſt thou think thou haſt ſo little ſhare in young Antonio, that thou dareſt ſpeak of comfort?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, on my life, Antonio is not dead.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bubulcus, on my ſoul's a very coward, and durſt as well attempt to take a prey out of a Tygers jaws, as ſee a ſword with patience bent againſt him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But Cowards in deſpair prove deſparate, and moſt unhappy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A my conſcience I could beat him into a mouſe-hole.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay, I could beat him, and I am ſure you can beat me, wu'd I were well rid of you: 'tis a double miſery to be abus'd, and dare not ſpeak out.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Here's Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Not guilty, not guilty, and pleaſe your Worſhips, let me not be hang'd for a lye of mine own making: 'tis well known I am a ſtinkingcoward: not guilty, I beſeech you; I never drew ſword in anger in my life: if you hang me, you undo me for ever.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Look you, ſir, 'tis clear.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My conſcience is a clear as Chriſtal: not guilty, my Lord, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Didſt not thou kill Antonio then?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Let me be hang'd if I did.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay, he'l confeſs.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I confeſs I told a lie, thinking to have got ſome credit: but if ever I ſaw Antonio, ſince he gave me two or three kicks, which I deſerv'd well enough, broyl me ath' coals. Mercy, oh mercy: do not caſt me away upon the Hangman now, in the pride of my youth: not guilty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Howſoever fear of death poſſeſs him ſo, I ſee the murther in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My eyes? wu'd they were out then: do you ſee murther in my eyes? are my eyes blood-ſhot?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: His very hand doth ſhew a guiltineſs, look how it trembles.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The fear of hanging hath put my whole body into palſey: My hands guilty? I can waſh my hands clean of it, I never kill'd a Fly. By this hand, not guilty.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.p: Which is Cornelio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This: what's the matter? what makes this Shepherd here?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am Cornelio: is it with me thou wood'ſt?

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: If your name Cornelio be,

l.hi: Contentment and felicity
I bring you: I am ſent from one
That doth call himſelf your ſon,

sp.l: Young Antonio, who thus low

l.hi: Would beg your bleſsing, prays that no
Affliction too much you diſmay
For his abſence, bad me ſay,
If you daine ſuſpend your care,
A few hours, and repaire
Ʋnto the place of Shepherds by,
To grace their pleaſures with your eye,

sp.l: Antonio will himſelf declare,

l.hi: Faithfully what cauſes were
Of his abſence, and requite
Theſe dolours with a freſh delight:
And ſo farewel. This is all:
Back again I hear them call.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh ſtay awhile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He's gone, ſir: did I not tell you, Antonio was not dead? but this is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Do I not dream?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Antonio among the Shepherds? if he be there, I am dreſt 'Ifaith: By any means, go ſir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is Antonio alive again?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Yes verily, alive again, let not the Hangman fright away your wits any longer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall chooſe my own Gallows then. Hillaria, you would not believe me: did I look as I had kild any body? now I hope you will hold me for an innocent hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Bubulcus, pray let us have your Company, it doth concern your freedom. Antonio living? Rufaldo, let us make a merry day on't, if it be true. I do ſin againſt Diſcretion to diſtruſt it. O my ſtars, I do acquit you all your injuries, if you poſſeſſe me of Antonio. Never did man to bliſs more willing go.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am glad I am repriev'd: come Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twere pretty if Antonio be multiplied:
Here's tricks indeed, I am reſolv'd to ſee
What will the end of this confuſion be,

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Never was Jenkin in ſuch Wilderneſs, her have walked and travelled creat deal of miles in theſe Woods: but her can finde no end nor evaſions, look you: her have read in Hiſtories, and Relations, and Kernicles, very famous Knights, and prave Sentilmen of valors, and ſhivalries have been enchaunted, look you, in Caſtles and very ſtrange dwellings, and Towers, and ſolitary places, now was have great fears and ſuſpicions, leſt Jenkin was fallen into ſome Wiſheries and Conjurations, and was inchaunted, bleſs us awl in theſe Deſarts and Wilderneſſes for her valors and magnanimities,

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: So ho, ho, Maſter Jenkin.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: It is our Page agen. Jocarello, where have you been? you are very tilligent Poyes, to loſe you Maſter thus.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: I was loſt my ſelf, had not a Shepherd by chance found me, and carried me into his houſe under the ground, where with a great many of Shepherdeſſes we ſate up all night in making Garlands for ſome ſhew and paſtimes to be done this day, which they call their Feſtival: pray, ſir, ſince we have run a wildegooſe chaſe ſo long, let's ſtay one day to ſee theſe ſports and dancings.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Sports and dances, ſay you? take pleaſures and delectations in dances? Very well, Jenkin was knaw how to dance her ſelf, was pred in awl Sentilmans qualities, look you, her will make no peregrinations back till awl be done, and it may be, was ſhake her legs in capers too, look you now.

div.stage: Enter Cornelio, Rufaldo, Antonio, Bubulcus, Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Maſter Jenkin, you are well met in theſe parts, I perceive you are early this morning, to partake the paſtimes of our Shepherds.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Good tayes and ſalutations, and cret deal of felicities come to awl your urſhips.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Sir, my name is Maſter Bubulcus, and I am as good a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: As who pray you? do you make compariſons?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I do embrace your familiarities, and remain your trueſt worm.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
Not too much worms, nor familiarities pray you: ha Pages, here is Selina's in her own apparels and veſtiments, awl was very true as our Countrey-woman Eccho's was make reports: Selina was gone back agen: very well: Miſtriſs Selina's was very full of joys and exhillarations, to ſee you in theſe places, you knaw how creatly and ardently Jenkin was taken with your peauties, and pulchritudes, cret while ago: pray, when did you
make returns out of theſe woods? Jenkin had knowledge, and ſaw you in your Shepherd apparels, and was make ambulations after you hither, out of meer amors and affections as her was true Sentilman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I make return out of theſe woods? I entred them but now.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, you deſire not to have things declared, and publiſhed, her was keep awl ſilences.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Upon my life you are miſtaken quite in this, Mr. Jenkin.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh, pray you make not Jenkin ridicles, and deriſions, look you, ſhall hear no more of that matters, call you only to memories you promiſed loves to Jenkin, pray you in matrimonies creat while ago.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I deny not that, ſir, but I know not why you have long neglected me, and I am now married to Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Rufaldo's? hit is not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Father, he ſays it is impoſſible Selina ſhould be your wife.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How, not my wife? I would fain ſee that.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Is Selina your wifes in truths and verities pray you?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Do you make queſtion? My wife? I think there is ſome reaſon, ſhe is my very dear wife, I will aſſure you ſir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He has got a boy by this time.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: A boy? well, I have got ſomething, a pox a your fingers. How ſaiſt? is not ſomething done, Sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, in my conſcience ſomething is done.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Jenkin was never awl his days have ſuch injuries and contumelies put upon her: was ever Sentilman thus abuſed? have her made repetitions and genealogies of her plood, for no matrimonies? Jenkin has peat the puſhes, and Rufaldo's has get the pirds. Hum! her love not to make quarrels and prabbles, but Jenkin could fight with any podies in the urld, awl weapons, from the long Pikes to the Welſh-hooks, look you now, no matrimonies? her Welſh-plood is up, look you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Maſter Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Maſter Blew-pottles, have you any ſtomacks or appetites to have any plows or knogs upon your coſtards, look you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No great ſtomack at this time, ſir, I thank you: alas, I have 'em every day, they are no novelties with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Come, Maſter Jenkin, I now perceive you lov'd my daughter, if you had acquainted me in time, I ſhould not have been nuwilling to have cal'd you ſon, but ſince 'tis too late, let your wiſedome
check impatience: I know you are of a noble remper, howſoever paſſion may a little cloud your vertues, lets be all friends I pray.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Here is very cood honeſt words, yes, look you, Jenkin is in aw I amities and friendſhips, but—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh, no more ſhooting at that butt: hark, I hear the Shepherds Muſick, and voice too, lets fit down I pray, Antonio keep thy word.

div.stage: Muſick. Enter Shepherds and Shepherdeſſes with garlands.

l.hi: Wood-men Shepherds, come away,

lg.l: This is Pans great holy-day,

l.hi: Throw off cares,
With your heaven aſpiring airs
Help us to ſing
While valleys with your Ecchos ring.
Nymphs that dwell within theſe groves,
Leave your Arbors, bring your loves,
gather poſies,
Crown your golden hair with Roſes,
As you paſs
Foot like Fayries on the graſs.
Joy drown our bowers, Philomel,

lg.l: Leave of Tereus rape to tell,

l.hi: Let trees dance,
As they at Thracian Lire did once,
Mountains play,
This is the Shepherds holiday.

div.stage: Dance. The ſong ended, Enter a mask of Satyrs, &c. and dance. Enter a Shepherdeſs with a white rod.

l.hi: Poſt hence Satyres and give way,
For fairer ſouls to grace the day,
And this preſence, whip the air
With new raviſhings, hence with care,
By the forelock hold Time faſt,
Leſt occaſion ſlip too faſt
Away from us, joys here diſtill.
Pleaſures all your boſoms fill.

div.stage: Enter Infortunio, Selina, Gaſparo, Felice, Gorgon, Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Fair Nymph, vouchſafe the honor to dance with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Troth, ſir, I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: We know you are Selina.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Your hand, faireſt.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Diſdain not, gentle ſir.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Pible pables, with awl her hearts, look you.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Noble ſir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Fair Lady, at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: I will not change.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Which is Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: It will break out anon.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You are a thief.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You have rob'd Selina

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then Ile make reſtitution, what are you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The Devil you are! faith, deal honeſtly with me, and Ile be true to thee: who art?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am Selina by my hopes of heaven.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ſiſter then!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I have no brother but Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I am he. Oh happineſs!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: If thou beeſt Antonie, what made thee aſſume my habit?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of that anon. Lives Infortunio?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: He's here, and with him Gaſparo and my ſiſter the loſt Felice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am raviſht with this wonder.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Keep your face conſtant: the Muſick calls.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha, what means this?

sp.speaker: Ant. Selina. Fel.
sp.p: Your bleſsing, ſir, we are your Children.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am Selina, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Amazement! thou Antonio? he Selina?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, how's this, my wife become a man? I confeſs ſhe plaid the man with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But who is this?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I am Felice, ſir, your long loſt Daughter,
Found out by Gaſparo, unto whom my vowes
In Heaven were long ſince ſacred, and I beg
Once more he may be mine.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: As I to be poſſeſt by Infortunio here.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay children, ſtay: take heed, you do not know what ſtrength of joy my fainting age can bear: you fall in too full ſhowres, like ſwelling Nile, theſe comforts will exceed the narrow banks of my poor frailty: Riſe, enjoy your wiſhes, and my bleſsings be multiplyed upon you. Ha! Rufaldo, here's Felice my loſt Girl, take her, take her, Gaſparo. Selina, art not thou Rufaldo's Wife?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No ſir, I ventured that, he knows me well, Hilaria and I were bed-fellows, at his requeſt.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How? Hillaria and you bedfellows? I'de laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am abus'd, diſgrac'd, undone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nay, Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then it ſeems you were Antonio, that I killd ſo, and you have, as a man ſhould ſay, lain with Hillaria beforehand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am not behind hand.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, and you have tickled her before and behind, tickle her all over for Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hark you, is there another Selina's? bleſs us awl, here is very prave love-tricks, look you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Bleſſing on him: why he hath made Stockfiſh on me, he has beaten away all my inclination to give my bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Come, upon recollection, you muſt make it a bargain: they have, it ſeems, bought and ſold already, 'tis paſt recovery, he ſhall be worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, that you may with more alacrity let fall your bleſſings: know, our blouds are pure, Antonio and your Daughter are as chaſte from any ſinful act, as when we were firſt mantled after birth.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, ſaiſt ſo?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas none of my fault, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Then my bleſſings to you: come, y'are both my Children.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Amen, and mine: Why I am rapt beyond my ſelf with joys. Infortunio, Fate hath effected that I beg'd of Heaven in many prayers for you, oh my bliſſes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: So, ſo, I am guld, my houſe taken o're my head.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Sir, you know who I am, I am yet walking Terra incognita, I have a great mind to Bubulcus, you know what I have ſuffered for him, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Let me alone, ſo, ſo: then pleaſures run with a ſtream upon us, but if we ſhall make a full day on't, here's one more to meet with her match, this poor Virgin hath been long in love with Bubulcus: troth, ſir, look upon her at length pitifully complaining: alas good ſoul, be honeſt at length: prethee do, and marry her, you know what has paſt between you, 'tis a hanſom Wench.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Umh, I do remember ſhe was in love with me, and ſo was twenty more: what's that to me? Alas, would you have me deſcend ſo low?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you ſung another ſong in my mothers Dairy, when we ſat up all night together, and had a Sack poſſet.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I do remember ſuch a thing, but what's that? Ile tak' t upon me.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I beſeech you, Gentlemen, ſpeak for me, for I will have him, I am aſham'd to ſhew my reaſons.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Very ſmall ones: away you durty quean.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: What, has he got thee with child?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: More then that, ſir,

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Has he had any Baſtards?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
Indeed Miſtriſs, Ile tell you; he hath begot
three children of my body.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Fie upon't, no leſs then three Baſtards.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How? nay, ſhe lies faſly, I got but two, ſo many I will acknowledge, becauſe they ſhall not doubt my ſufficiency, had I any more then two, ſpeak you lying whore.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Sir, I tender your credit, there is but two ways, either you muſt marry her, or give her a piece of money, that's the eaſieſt way, ſhe is poor: for your reputation—

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What do you think will content the Whore?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hark you, beſt for you, make ſome ſatisfactions to this Sentilwoman, or Senkin was learn you more honeſties and behaviours towards theſe umans, warrant you Maſter blew pottles.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: A matter of twenty or thirty pieces, you can ſpare them.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: You Strumpet, here's twenty pieces for you: do you hear? keep well the boys then: but you ſhall ſwear, before theſe Gentlemen, you will never claim marriage: then, be an honeſt woman hereafter.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Yes, bear witneſs, Gentlemen, I do accept his wiſe benevolence, and will never trouble him with marriage— whilſt Gorgon lives.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Your ſervant, and your pardons: nay, Gorgon has had his devices and vagabunduloes as well as the beſt on ye: give you all joy, I wiſh you wit, ſir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am fool'd of all ſides, was I a born fool?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Stay you, Maſter double colours, there be more fools in the buſineſs as your ſelf: well Jenkin, were even beſt make ſhurneys back into her own Countreys, and never put credits or conferences in any womans in the whole urld: they all lie and coozen, and make deriſions out awl meaſures.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Nay, nay, Gentlemen, let's all together,
We • l drown all diſcontents this day with wine,
Let's take up all our Fates then, and proclaim
This day new Feſtivals in Hymens name.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay a little, and Ile along with you. Since I have miſt my Wench, I le ask theſe Gentlemens good wils to a ſecond match, in ſtead of an Epilogue.
Courteous Spectators, and kinde Gentlemen. —

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Why, how now? what, are you mad? will you ſpeak the Epilogue? though you have plaid a fool in the Play, you will not ſhew your ſelf an Aſſe before all this company. The Epilogue? I hope I am the wiſer ath' two, and the better read in Complement.
Judicious Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Hark you, Maſter double-colours, and you goody Gorgons, here is one wiſer, Aſſes you both, to pronounce the Epilogues, warrant you, and one, that knaws—to ſpeak in as good Engliſh, Gentlemen, now ſans Complement.

l.hi: OƲr Love-tricks have been ſhewn, and we attend
To know if your acceptance Crown the end,
The World is full of Tricks, but it will be
A Trick worth all, to have ſome Plaudite
To theſe of Love. If then contentment dwell
On you, we ſhall conclude, our Play ſhews well,
Which we did Love-tricks call, that you might prove
It was a Trick of ours to gain your Love.

div.p: Printed for Thomas Dring, at the White Lion in Fleetſtreet; Where you may be furniſhed with moſt ſorts of Plays.
